moves.1. e4 e5 2. d4: usually leads to a centre game if black takes....
moves.5. Bxb2: takes the long diagonal, and now the material advantage is his, but i control most of the board
moves.5... Ne7: not the best defence here, d5 is actually book, while d5 does give me back a pawn, it opens up blacks pieces very nicely, ne7 leads to an even more cramped position
moves.6. Nf3: developing, preparing to castle, and bring the rook into play
moves.6... d5: he now tries to gambit the pawn back to me, after blocking his bishop in, not the best move really, Bg5 was better
moves.7. exd5: i take the free pawn, but i can't afford to trade the bishop off yet, as im still down a pawn, and owning the diagonals is paramount in the Danish Gambit
moves.8... Bd6: starts a kingside push, prepares to castle
moves.9. Re1+: forces him to retreat either the knight or the bishop and lets me take the pawn on g7
moves.9... Ne7 10. Bxg7: now material has been equalized and i have a far superior position, note that his king is still in the middle of the board and his queen, bishop, and both knights are stuck
moves.10... Rg8: tries to drive out the bishop, puts his rook on a file with my king
moves.11. Qd4: i decide to try to keep the pressure on his struggling king
moves.11... a6: bit of a waste of time, preparing b5 to drive away my bishop, which needs to move anyway
moves.12. Bd3: i preempt his move and attack the pawn on h7 which would also win a bishop-rook exchange
moves.12... c5: he tries to drive out my queen and give his pieces some room
moves.13. Qf6: i have to guard the bishop and the pressure on his king is mounting
moves.13... Nd7: this move was intended to move my queen away, but look at his king, completely trapped by his own pieces, and ready to fall
moves.14. Qg5: keeps the guard on the bishop
moves.15. Bg6+: his pawn move opened up a diagonal to his king, and because his knight is pinned, none of his pieces can defend, all he can defend with is a rook pawn
